awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Long Term Establishment of Social Interactive Ties
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates how social traditions may adapt long-distance economies to local community structures. Previous research suggested that long-distance economies generate inequality by creating opportunities for greater wealth hoarding and status differentiation with prestige goods from distant regions – thereby dissolving local community bonds. However, historians and ethnographers have instead discovered multiple case studies of group-oriented societies altering how long-distance economies interface to limit activities such as wealth-hoarding and blunting the overall inequality. Archaeologists in particular have found examples of major urban settlements involved in long-distance economies that instead retained community-based social structures. Such group-oriented societies are often maintained through regular community-building practices steeped in values of tradition. While it was previously thought that long-distance economies have a “homogenizing” effect, economy rarely overrides tradition and both often intertwine to produce diverse social outcomes. Investigating how long-distance economies localize in such societies will then further understanding on the many possible trajectories cultures undertake in globalizing spheres all over the world.

This project specifically aims to examine the outcomes of community-building practices on the localization of long-distance economies through mortuary ceramics. Ceramics often index the circulation of goods in the archaeological record, and mortuary ceramics specifically were often curated as prestige or ritual materials. This project focuses on a region which over long periods of time was involved in long distance trade. Associated mortuary traditions appear to have limited wealth hoarding and status differentiation and instead encouraged community-building dynamics through ceramic material. In collaboration with a research reactor, this project will employ compositional analysis that differentiates ceramic manufactures to examine how such ceramics circulated and were ultimately deposited in tombs. The acquired data would then show who was involved in such exchanges and ultimately allow for evaluation of how successfully community-building practices helped preserve a group-oriented social structure in the context of long-distance trade. The project data will also be used to prepare public-facing visual materials that summarize archaeological research for stakeholders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigates how long-distance economies impact local social ties. Previous research has shown differences between social traditions that promote group-building actions and values, such as reciprocal obligation and community responsibility, and those where people operate on individual self interest. A common argument is that long-distance economies disrupt community dynamics by providing alternative sources for goods so that are people are no longer obligated to maintain their local social networks. This further creates the impression that globalized economies eventually dissolve local communities and encourage the growth of urban landscapes driven by self interested actors. However, archaeologists and historians see a multitude of cases that counter this idea, such as urban settlements with group-oriented community layouts, or cultural regions that used long-distance goods in community-building economic exchanges. This project examined one such case where an urban community appears to have invented new social traditions to maintain their local connections with each other in a globalizing economy.

This  project carried out archaeological research to investigate local social networking through grave materials at an ancient trading capital called Aksum in northern Ethiopia. Aksum was the capital of a major trading polity (50BCE - 800CE) that dominated the Indian Ocean sea routes that connected three continents - part of the popularly labeled "Silk Road" economy. Aksum is famous for its towering funerary obelisks and cemetery sites, which were built during the height of its role in this economy (50BCE - 400CE). Notably, foreign materials are not found among Aksumite grave goods, suggesting that social ceremonies of death may be one way Aksumites maintained traditional community-oriented lifeways in a globalizing economy.  The project then analyzed the most common grave good - a redware pottery - found across three very different tombs that suggest three different wealth stratums within the community. Analyzing the composition of these pots could show whether different wealth stratums obtained their goods from different producers and held diverging social networks. 135 ceramic samples were investigated using Neutron Activation Analysis at the Missouri Research Reactor (MURR) to examine their compositional manufacture and circulation across the cemetery. 5 additional AMS radiocarbon dates from skeletal material were also sent to the University of Arizona AMS lab to examine how we could compare skeletal and ceramic data.

Results indicate that the cemetery community held social ties that cross-cut overt differences in wealth. Five broad chemical groups - like representing different potters or manufactures - overlapped the different tombs. These graves varied widely in size, elaboration, and ostensible displays of wealth, but results indicate that people remained integrated through funeral ceremonies and death rites that led to the burial of these grave goods. In such cases, elites held similar social networks as those buried in simple graves, and their access to these types of goods were not restricted from each other. This suggests that globalization did not drive the dissolution of community ties, but that the urban population instead invented new social ceremonies maintain their connections to each other. In the larger theme, this case study then shows how people's social traditions can guide economic transformations brought by globalization.

Overall, this research demonstrated the different outcomes of long-distance trade on a local urban community - specifically as seen through the window of death traditions and the circulation of funerary objects. The research then contributes to a larger field showing the many possible ways communities can direct their own social and economic transformations in globalizing environments.

The research in this study is intended to be considered by individuals with working interests in archaeological case studies on the intersections of long-distance economies with local community dynamics, and general publics interested in understanding social transformations in globalized environments, the place of death and burial in globalizing economies, tradition and globalization, and the varied pathways of inequality.
